Definition: Determine whether or not the given comment is Obscene. Any depiction or description of sexual topics that offends moral principles is referred to as obscenity.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

The team slowly fell apart and conveniently Lacroix retires so that his "genius" reputation as a GM stayed in tact. Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... This, as we're seeing today, was a MASSIVE mistake. Gary Crum

This kind of what matters to Honolulu and screw the rest of you mentality exposes a flaw in the majority take all system we rely upon here. 

A system that is bias to Oahu at the expense of all the outer islands suggests in the long run some amount of autonomy must be sought. If Oahu can not care for the outer islands, it is long overdue for the outer islands to be granted the right, and share of state funds, to care for themselves.

We have seen this inequity played out time and time again. From our schools to our infrastructure needs. Our healthcare facilities lack, our environmental concerns are not protected, we are not protected from invasive species, but damn Oahu gets its rail. At some point there's got to be a reckoning. 

Thank you Russell.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: " ... fresh off their meeting with the UN committee in Geneva earlier this week" ...
I am assuming that they (as always) flew First Class ... and stayed in the finest hotels. Geneva is so lovely at this time of the year. 

I wonder if they had lunch with Bono.

In the autumn of 1971 I was standing on a dock in northern Manitoba ... a newly-minted school-teacher attending an orientation session before heading still further north. A young native guy walks out along the dock and joins me at the end. A beautiful evening. Silence. Maybe geese overhead ... 

He speaks ... not to me ... but out ... clearly ... onto the big calm lake.

"There is an old legend from my people. <pause> If a hunter makes a very strong bow ... and goes out onto the land and shoots an arrow straight up into the sky ... <pause again> it will strike a large airplane. And on that airplane there will be at least one Indian going to a conference."

Buddy turned to me, smiled mischievously.

You can't "make-up" this shit.

Comment: We do love the Church. If we didn't, we would have left years ago. We reject YOUR idea of the Church, but that's something else entirely. 

We think that abandoning "orientation, liturgical language, liturgical music" is a good thing. Having the priest stand with his back to the congregation, mumbling in a language most of the laity do not speak, is a terrible way of having a communal worship service. Religious music is one of the best examples of "Sturgeon's Law" I know of (the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon was told, "Ninety percent of sf is crud", to which he replied "Ninety percent of EVERYTHING is crud".) Yes, today's music also exemplifies Sturgeon's Law.

BTW, Montanism was not condemned solely for having women priests. It was largely condemned for its theological beliefs. Your statement is simplistic at best.

We think about the teachings. If they give us good arguments, we accept them. Crap gets rejected. The arguments against ordaining women are crap, for example.

Similarly, North Africa went from a verdant land of rivers, woods, and grasslands, populated by people and magnificent African game, to the world's largest desert.

Comment: This matter of course is nuanced by country and culture.  In Peru, perhaps other Andean countries, some clergy are very open about their committed but of course "unmarried" relationship to a woman and "their" children. When the parishioners know with whom the priest is sleeping, they can usually rest assured that he is not on the prowl for other liaisons.  While in some countries a common slur might be "hijo de puta" or "son of a whore", in Peru it more commonly would be "hijo de cura" or "son of a priest", because that is the equivalent of "bastard" being that the biological father is forbidden from marrying his defacto common-law wife. But an honorable priest would be expected to adequately care for his "wife" and children, and this reality is tolerated because it is the people or community (sensus fiedelium) who not only support but at times require that a priest have an attachment. In the rest of the world, fooling around is just that and borders on abuse which is traditional.

Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: Outsider:  Damn it, man, I really enjoy arguing with you, and on this one it's really hard.  With population growth, urbanization and industrialization in, as you point out, especially China and India, our "carbon footprint" just keeps growing.  The best we can do is to try to "slow it down."  Unless there's a concerted and coordinated worldwide commitment to address all the factors (including population growth), we're doomed to ever-increasing and ever-accelerating warming. 

Yes, we should do what we can to slow it.  But, at the same time, we'd best make significant strides toward needed long-term adjustments to live with it as best we can.  That includes such things as decreased "waste" of water, and reassessing what locations are habitable....especially, already extremely dry areas and very low elevation and vulnerable coastal regions.  It won't be pretty.   Regards, Gary

Comment: Anyone who is not panicking does not understand the problem. You seem to be pinning your hopes of supply continuity on borehole (ground) water for mass supply. There are no other solutions apart from rain. My understanding is that there are 6 established drillers in CT who understand local conditions with an average order book which stretches 6 months or more into the future. These are confirmed orders on which deposits have been paid by homeowners. I have a quote from one of these drillers for late April 2018. They are not available to drill for the COCT. There are fly by nights from other provinces but they do not understand local drilling conditions and are far less likely to succeed. This is crucial. There is also a high failure rate on new boreholes. 

It is impossible for me to quantify precise savings. However my argument is that existing supplies are inadequate for existing population numbers and this is the imperative for halting population growth until supply matches demand

Comment: ..." You just have new players in the real estate market with loads of money and native Canadian can't compete."...

Exactly.

We also have a new way of doing real estate business.  

Here in metro Vancouver, entire condo projects are marketed overseas and sold in pre-sales.  Appetite for housing units as a commodity is so high in China that they have 60 million sold and empty homes. 

A quote from a recent G+M story from a RE agent states that "demand is unlimited" for Vancouver condos sold overseas. 

This commodification of housing is so entrenched here in metro Vancouver, that it is estimated that 47% of the condos in Richmond city centre are sold and empty, and about 25% of the new condos built at metro Vancouver rapid transit hubs are sold and empty.

New players, new money, and  a new view of what residential real estate should be.

Comment: I grew up in the Anchorage area and hunted ptarmigan and grouse many times with my dad. Dad's gone and I know longer hunt, but I still remember those days fondly. My dad taught me to appreciate the sometimes perplexing contradictions of a wilderness lover. He grew up a farm boy and saw the bounty of the wilds--plants and animals--as something to be harvested, just like on the farm. He also fought hard for wilderness--including many places that didn't allow hunting--and was an avid bird watcher. I miss him.

Comment: I am not sure when teaching simple facts and skills ends and teaching morality starts. Is the teaching of listening and evaluating claims in an objective manner teaching of morality?
Let's assume a teacher is imposing their beliefs on the class that one should regard all people, regardless of race, national origin, sexual orientation, disability or religious affiliation, as equal. Is that teaching morality? Let's say a family teaches their child that Whites or Blacks are superior, and the teacher teaches they are equal. Is that teaching undermining the parent's rights to teach their children what they believe is true?
Continuing our scenario, assume a teacher puts forth that all people are born equal because the Declaration of Independence says so. Is the teaching of the Declaration of Independence teaching morality? It sure seems like a moralistic statement to me.
Sure, people will argue that sexual orientation and religion are choices. But does this make them less equal as people?

  Everyone I've ever had does something else for a living. They use uber as some extra money on the side. Especially during big events in there area when there are more than enough customers to go around for them and the cab drivers. 
 They fill in during high demand times. You know, those times where there is s high demand for cabs but since the number of cabs is static, riders end up waiting.....and waiting......and waiting for a cab. 

    Perfect example:
   Yesterday my son needed a ride from Scottsdale to the Phoenix airport at 5am. It's about a 30 min ride. A cab company quoted us $60-70 based on traffic. 
    
   We prescheduled an uber the night before for 4:30 am for $27. Turns out the driver lives in Scottsdale and works at the airport. (Drives a new BMW) he told my son he can almost always pick up a rider on his commute to and from work. That's $50 a day for him without even going out of his way.

Comment: Along the same lines, one way to estimate the total cost of the carbon tax would be to average out Ontario's inflation rates for at least a few months in 2017 vs. the inflation rates in Provinces like Manitoba and Quebec (who didn't bring out a new carbon tax) during the same months.

For example, for January Ontario saw 2.3% year-over-year inflation vs. 1.3% in Quebec and 2.1% in Manitoba.  Of course there is a lot of variation and other reasons why inflation might be lower or higher in any given month, hence why averaging out over a longer of period of time can help "smooth things out".

Sill it is not unreasonable to guess that Ontario's Cap 'n Trade added maybe 0.6 percentage points to inflation, averaging inflation here vs. Manitoba and Quebec.  So if your family's after-tax income is $50,000/year the cap'n'trade tax might be costing you about $300/year?

Actually the cap'n'trade tax is expected to be a bit regressive, so with $50,000/year income it probably costs more than $300.

Comment: I'm all for Uber and/or Lyft to start working up here, because needless to say, our Taxi situation isn't great.... but that said, the Senate majority did the whole State a massive disservice by refusing to consider amendment after amendment that would have eeked out a little more protection for Alaskans. For example, there is no requirement for Uber/Lyft drivers to have an Alaska driver's license! No requirement for their car to be registered in Alaska! There's no provision for Workmen's Compensation for the drivers! 

And to top it all off, the bill is utterly toothless, as the Finance Committee stripped out all the language allowing the Dept. of Commerce to do anything. So, sure, there's a requirement for insurance on the vehicle, etc, but there's nothing behind that requirement. No insurance? No problem. 

We have to hope that the House Majority takes a critical look at this and adds back in some sorely needed bones.

Comment: MacKinnon does not properly describe either the dangers facing Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) or its accomplishments. Because its currency is pegged to the euro it has been more successful in maintaining price stability than Serbia; it has now received candidate status from the EU; EU membership is likely only a matter of time. The main danger to Bosnia and Herzegovina came from the self-styled war heroine of Tuzla Airport, Hillary Clinton, promoting a unitary state for BiH rather than a federation. Reasonable people can agree to disagree over how the federation should be structured; possibly giving a Croat entity the same status as Republika Srpska has some merit. However, but for now at least, not even a quarter of century after the Bosnian war, only a federation makes sense.  MacKinnon ignores the disgraceful ethnic cleansing of Kosovo of its Serb and Roma population in the wake of the NATO victory as well as the cultural genocide: the destruction of Orthdox churches and landmarks.

Comment: This bee (and others) is probably a victim of technology.  Note that it has disappeared from "large scale farming areas".  In the past, farmers had fence rows to show them where their property ended.  The fence rows contained long strips of weedy looking flowers  (just the kind that bees like because those weedy flowers are an abundant source of nectar and pollen which feeds the bees).  Now the farmers use GPS (global positioning system) to tell them where their property ends.  So the farmers ripped out the fences and the weedy flowers and grow crops on every inch  (metric equivalent is two and a half centimeters) of their property.  Crops are generally grasses like corn and wheat, which contain no food value for bees.  The fence rows also provided an area where the bees could build their nests, which would be left undisturbed by farm machinery (bumble bees build "nests").   Added together, the fence rows contained quite a lot of land that would need to be restored to rebuild habitat.

Comment: We need an income tax to pay for basic services. Here is just a sample of what I consider basic services: getting roads plowed in our neighborhoods and having snow removed in our cul-de-sacs and sidewalks on a timely basis; enable schools to provide basic school supplies and not ask parents to buy $150 of supplies at the start of the school year; build and repair roads and bridges in the summertime; provide public transportation. Improved library services and enhanced funding for colleges to maintain and grow its programming. Let's attract talent! This is what makes a place livable. And these expenses are just for the cities. The people off the road system have their own needs that also must be provided for. A graduated income tax is fair. A sales tax is not -- a single mother making $20,000 a year feels a 5% (or whatever percent) tax on a purchase a lot more than someone making $60,000 a year. We used to have an income tax and a school tax, and no dividend. The free ride is over.

Comment: In most cases, both you and the prosecutor want to avoid a trial with higher charges vs settling. A jury is unpredictable. In addition, how the facts come out at trial is uncertain-- A witness forgetting a detail, a bad question by the prosecution, a witness never telling your story because of a good prosecutor or bungling by your attorney. In addition to risk, the cost of a trial can be too high for you to afford and this may mean cutting your defense short-- you may not be able to afford the top mainland or Hawaii expert witnesses. The defense has bargaining leverage because the prosecutor is always pressed for time and money required to take a case to trial (on top of the risk that it will be easy for the defense to show "reasonable doubt"). A good defense attorney can exploit this. Defense attorney's know that certain cases that fit certain patterns are avoided by prosecutors and are easy to settle.

Comment: Investing in a corp is just a tax deferral strategy like the RRSP, however the corp has no max and investments still retain their tax treatments, but no deduction. This money typically is invested in Canadian companies, for the dividend, and is  a small perk for the risk taking involved. The T4 employee takes no risk other than their time and have all the protections of the various employment law. An employer takes all the business, market, legal, financing, and employee risk. With this thinking the two should not be compared and should be treated differently as we live in a free market society and should encourage risk taking; because the more successful small businesses there are the more efficient a free market society becomes. Instead this will encourage  people to seek employment and centralize their risk to fewer companies. This leads to market inefficiency and can lead to income disparity. We need entrepreneurship and they need rewards to make the leap.

Comment: Re : the comment that the tax code is often used to encourage certain types of behaviour.  The author assumes that this is a good thing without providing any justification. Perhaps one reason why we are so far removed from the perfect world of no accountants that is described in the first sentence is because governments try to use the tax code for more than raising revenue, making it too complex. Further, even if changing behaviour is an appropriate use of the tax code, the statement that doctors practice medicine in the same fashion whether they are incorporated or not seems false. The limited liability offered through incorporating encourages doctors to invest more of their wealth into expensive diagnostic tools and other capital intensive equipment. They should  be allowed to depreciate these assets and receive a return on investment in the form of a dividend the same as any other business.

Comment: Digby,

A couple of things.

Hearing loss can also occur because of illness.   Viruses or bacteria involving high fever are a significant cause of sudden hearing loss at any age.   The younger this happens, the more serious this can be, especially if speech hasn't fully developed.   In those cases, speech therapy is needed.   And, for the record, an otolaryngologist told me the best thing for parents to do for children with hearing loss was to read aloud to them regularly and a lot, sitting with the text visible to the child. 

Sudden ear pressure change can burst the ear drums.

Research shows that children with early hearing loss are more likely to struggle in school (regardless of the use of hearing aids) and if the diagnosis is delayed or missed, they are more likely to be incarcerated as adults.   In addition to the social problems caused by miscommunication, people assume they are insubordinate and respond with punishment.   This can escalate and become a serious problem.

Comment: As I understand it, this is a privately-initiated application to add this site to the Goal 5 inventory.  The county doesn't seek out potential quarry sites to add to the inventory; it's always the owners of these properties that initiate this process.  And the county can't just say no thanks.  Once an application is filed, the county is required to apply the relevant law and make a decision.  They can always choose to ignore the controlling law and deny these applications, but without a basis for doing that they will just see it again on remand from the inevitable appeal.  That, of course, would increase the cost to the owner, but it also adds to the county's (i.e. your and my) costs and the result ends up the same.  What's the benefit there?  

The Goal 5 inventory process is expensive and I get why the county balks at taking that on on a county-wide basis. But, nothing I know of prevents nonprofits from funding the necessary studies or initiating their own inventory process.

You have the moral right to choose to have these procedures, and should have the obligation to pay for them. Perhaps a loan process would be needed, however, for those incapable of paying the costs up front.

Comment: Relax.

If there's a nuclear war, every half-way decent sized city in the world will vanish within a few hours of each other. If you live in a city that's been bombed, you might not even notice you've been bombed because the signals might not have time to register in your brain before you die. For all intents and purposes, about 54% of the world's population (city dwellers) in an all out nuclear exchange will die a very speedy death, leaving the remaining 46% (the rural inhabitants) having to endure a few days of radiation sickness before they die.

Conventional warfare lasting years or decades is much scarier. Can you imagine the on-going life of a six year old Syrian child from 2011 to now? Scary. Or a Yemeni 10 year old now? Scary.

Comment: When I was  7 years old my family lived in Houston and attended an Episcopalian church.    In the front of the chapel was a stain glass of Jesus with arms lowered and outstretched, like a father waiting for a hug.   Being that young and the Episcopalian church being formal, I didn't 'get' the liturgical stuff, or sermons.   I would grab a pencil from the pew and one of the paper programs and start to doodle.   

I remember trying to draw that stain glass during the service and it seems that Jesus would move in ways that you had to look hard to see.  I think he spoke to me but I don't remember any words?   It felt wonderful and personal. 

So, I suppose my morals come from my perception of how I see the life of Jesus.    The emotion was that of the love of child for a parent. 

That small subtle voice has stayed with me.   The problem is that the Spirit wants me to sit quietly and frankly I'm not real good at it.

Comment: Mike, it sounds like you live in Enderby BC.  Semi-rural, it's nothing to do 50-100km in a day, if not more at steady speed conditions, even if it is winter.  That helps a lot.  Also, a nice big V8 (454!) keeps RPM low and those motors can last a lifetime with barely any servicing.

Some engines aren't designed as well.  Either the metallurgy isn't as durable, or the number and location of seals causes more oil leaks as the motor ages with time.  As the small-block chevy is "cam-in-block", there are fewer seals to deal with and long-term durability is improved.

Oil leaking from leaking gaskets and seals is the first step in the death-knell of a motor, as it allows engine oil LEVEL to drop between oil changes.  Low oil level does far more damage than an extended oil change interval.  

Also, oil filters will "fill up" far sooner than an oil's additive package will be consumed, so if one is trying to save money, changing the filter only and topping up every 2nd change is acceptable.

Comment: The most shameful case of failure to act to recovery is perhaps the one of the Lake Superior coastal caribou pictured in the article; among the easiest to observe or photograph in the past, these woodland caribou have a high educational value. They are also among the majority declining populations in Canada. Pukaskwa National Park did not act on reintroduction plans and the caribou are no longer there. And the anchor islands (the Slate Islands, Pic and Michipicoten islands in Lake Superior) that were once inaccessible to wolves now have routine wolf visits with anthropogenic origins for their visits. The Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources trapped the wolves from Michipicoten Island, but not to relocate them, just to study them while they killed and ate most of the caribou. I'd call that mismanagement.

Comment: I'm no fan of lawyers in general, but if he or she tells a potential client up-front how their fee will be charged, then the client has no cause for complaint later on, unless perhaps the lawyer mishandles the case. If the lawyer adds charges later on that were not previously discussed, that's another matter. The good lawyers earn every dime of what they charge their clients - whether it be on the basis of a flat fee per hour or a percentage of the final, collected settlement / judgement. As long as the client knows this before engaging the lawyer, then there can be no cause for complaint if the case is successful and the lawyer really works for it.

Comment: Ross, there were a few other serious floods, though the ones you mention were the biggies.  The point, though, is that serious flooding is happening more often than it did a century ago.  A number of reasons can be cited.  Yes, climate change is one of them.  Ever-increasing building in flood-prone areas is another.  

Probably the biggest is more effective drainage ditches.  Everyone wants to get the water off his land fast in the spring so he can get on with planting.   Nothing sinister about that, except that the water has to go somewhere.  The guy downstream gets it faster than he used to, so there is more flooding.  Digging more effective drainages started in the 1930s and accelerated after the war.  It is no coincidence that, in addition to the major flood in 1950, there were significant floods in 1948, 1956 and 1965.  Manitoba has built major flood controls to protect the cities, particularly Winnipeg, but these don't deal with the supply problem.

Comment: Many reasons. Tepees, in order to be warm and weather-proof, require animal skins: loads of animals roaming in herds AND the right to toodle around vast swathes of land hunting said animals -- neither of which requirements currently survives. Instead, the vast swathes of land were claimed by the Crown, and FN were herded onto reserves, their traditional practices outlawed, and their children taken away to receive an education that was intentionally shaped to un-FN them with contempt for, among other things, tepees. 
Plus, the reason for tepees is that if you find you're living in a place with unpotable water or not enough food or fuel, you can pick it up and move to a better spot. Moving is no longer allowed, and reserves were lands that no one else wanted, bad soil, whatever. On top of that, natural water sources were limited -- and on many reserves now have been catastrophically polluted by industry. 
In other words, we took away all the reasons tepees were good.

Comment: Humans exhibit various behaviours that, while advantageous earlier in our evolutionary history, are no longer desirable, e.g. the fight-or-flight reflex that gives so many people high blood pressure in fast-paced office environments.
  In this case, it appears reasonable to assume that groups with strong self-identification and a hierarchy of males often express and reinforce their structure via regular demonstrations of sexual dominance and submission, which is often symbolic, e.g. Weinstein masturbating in front of junior females, and not necessarily heterosexual, e.g. homosexual dominance in the Nazi SS.

  The value in this observation is that once a group falls into this behaviour pattern, all members participate and reinforce the pattern and accept it as necessary or inevitable, even if they don't like it.  Once we recognize that groups often exhibit this pattern, we can look for ways to jam the behaviour and morph it to a more appropriate group dynamic.

Comment: The 41% CDC figure does not relate to fluoridation. Fluoridation often has no discernible effect in the numbers. Where a slight increase in numbers is found (compared with non-fluoridated areas) the increase is only in the mildest forms which are usually assessed positively by teenagers and parents.

One has to be very careful about claims made by anti-fluoride activists as they are often wrong or completely misrepresent the science.

Have a read of this article https://openparachute.wordpress.com/2014/11/24/water-fluoridation-and-dental-fluorosis-debunking-some-myths/

Comment: No it is also China.
Long ago China got developing nation status which meant heavily subsidized postage to the 1st world. It costs less to send a parcel from China to Toronto than it does to send it from Vancouver to Toronto and Canada Post does 90% of the work involved. But now they have a space program and build aircraft carriers, etc. - I think they can manage to pay the same as Canadians do to send a parcel. Then the goods they send here basically never get charge duty or taxes - in part because they routinely misstate the value on their customs declaration.
However you are partly correct - Canada Post is very expensive for parcels. But note that couriers, e.g. Fedex and UPS, operating within Canada charge the same as Canada Post.
Part of the reason for this is the couriers made a trade panel complaints about Canada Post subsidizing parcel rates and they won. That was right about the time Canada Post bought Purolator.

Extend the pipeline to Delta Port and you dramatically reduce the potential harm.

Comment: There was no annexation of Crimea. The claim otherwise is more fake news, meant to hype people up into supporting a position that isn't grounded in reality, but stems from ulterior motives.
Crimea's democratically-elected government organized a referendum to rejoin Russia (as they'd been trying to do for over 25 years). After the referendum was successful, Crimea's government applied for accession to Russia. Crimea was an unbound region at that time, not a part of Ukraine, as Ukraine had ceased to exist as a legal or constitutional entity when its constitution was rendered null and void in February 2014 - meaning, there were no Ukrainian laws, and no Ukrainian territory.
The outcome of the Crimea referendum has been confirmed as authentic by over a half-dozen international pollsters, and Crimea has invited the UN to visit and witness the situation.
Listen to what former CIA agent Ray McGovern has to say about what happened in Ukraine, and Russia's response:

Comment: All the minutes of the Monetary Policy Committee meeting for 14 June said about US inflation was: “Core PCE inflation had fallen for the second month in a row, to 1.5%, its lowest rate since December 2015, although some of this appeared to reflect idiosyncratic factors.” Somewhat odd, since the US Fed actually targets the PCEPI, not any core measure, and its inflation rate was a stronger 1.7%, down from 1.9% in March. You really get an appreciation of what completely different tracks Yellen’s Fed and Calamity Carney’s Fed are on, if you look, instead, at the US HICP for the total population, almost exactly comparable to the UK HICP. (The only important sense in which it is not comparable is that it has biennial basket updates, unlike the annual basket updates for the UK CPI, which is also the UK HICP. This should, if both the UK and the US had the same true inflation rate, make the US inflation rate appear slightly higher.)

Comment: You need to understand the context of the phrase.

"I'm entitled to my entitlements." was statement by former Liberal Cabinet Minister David Dingwall who was forced out of his position as head of the Royal Mint by his political enemy PM Paul Martin. (Dingwall was Chretien loyalist).

Two  independent reports (one by Price Water House Cooper and the other by the law firm of Osler, Hoskin and Harcourt)  completely exonerated Dingwall and retired Superior Court Justice George Adams found that the Government of Canada essentially forced Dingwall out when he released his findings in a binding arbitration ruling.  In law it is known as constructive dismissal so there was nothing voluntary in his resignation.

So Dingwall was in fact entitled to his entitlements -  a severance package set out in his contract of employment.

BTW I am a long time Conservative (nigh on a half century) inspired by that great Conservative John Diefenbaker.

Comment: An article, such as this, that never discusses government spending cannot be considered to have addressed whether fiscal constraint has been exercised.  To discuss fiscal constraint, changes in government spending have to be analyzed.  Ideally, the benchmark should be real (i.e., after inflation) government spending per capita.  If that measure has increased less than the rate of real economic growth, then a strong argument can be made that a government has exercised fiscal constraint.

Comment: William,

There is a phenomenon that I have observed and experienced in many successful endeavors - we tend to become a "victim of our own success".

It is precisely BECAUSE the SDA church has been successful, that we need to intentionally and constructively address these issues, which otherwise become BARRIERS to future success.

In a very peculiar sense, we have a built-in contradiction in Adventist thinking.  Individually and institutionally, "success" constitutes reaching the point of irrelevance - when Jesus returns to take us ALL home the SDA church and its various institutions will cease to exist!

LDS and JW theologies ascribe a special role in the Afterlife, for their adherents.  Some Adventists do likewise with their emphasis on "last generation" or 144,000 motifs.

If we eschew these models (see Mt 20:1-16) then we must agree that the blessing accruing to Adventists is the blessing of serving others.  Our notion of "success" must change from "gaining" to "giving".

Comment: In 1972 David Crombie was running for mayor of Toronto. His slogan was "Small is beautiful". All the progressives, young and old, were behind him. He won by landslide. His tenure was one of the most successful in the history of the city. He and his entourage understood the meaning of "sustainable development" perfectly. The city government and the OMB did not crumble in front of the greedy developers. No one needed more and more condo projects so that they could get rich by flipping them. Development was orderly, respectful of the citizens' properties and wishes and manageable. There was hardly a "housing crisis" because migration to Toronto was also reasonable. No one thought that we needed a concrete jungle to house more people in the downtown core in order to increase the city's tax revenue exponentially to be spent politician salaries, city bureaucracy and unions and dubious projets.  The city was in harmony, with no envious "critics" pitting citizens against one another.

Comment: Over the years, predator-prey populations have developed biologic strategies to avoid the feast-famine cycling. In most systems absolute famine is avoided, but there are highs and lows. ADFG cannot tolerate the ungulate lows. In fact, this lack of tolerance for the lows is enshrined in the intensive management law. Citing its legal mandate, ADFG enters the natural system and "adjusts" it "scientifically"  to benefit human hunters. Over years, these adjustments can lead to an overabundance of the ungulates and increased pressure on habitat.  The mantra of hunter opportunity is thusly maintained. But lo, we see this system of management is imperfect and leads to heavy pressure on the predators and overabundance of the prey. Unit 13 comes to mind. I am convinced there is a better way to manage.

Comment: "On the other, it represents an admission of failure with treatment, and many taxpayers would greatly resent funding addicts."
In fact, in places that already prescribe heroin to addicts, a pattern of initial dose increase and then gradual but consistent decrease is regularly observed, concomitant with the stabilization of other areas of the patient's life -- housing, job, relationships, etc. (See results from Switzerland.)
In other words, prescription heroin is sometimes a path to abstention where other methods have failed.
As to funding addicts... society already pays enormous costs related to addiction, and these programs cost less per patient than the costs related to the patient's pre-treatment behavior/circumstance.

Comment: In a general sense I worry about what the statistics are really saying. For instance, for some unexplained  reason there are 2-and--half times more reports of sexual assault per capita in St. John, New Brunswick than in Toronto. If, as was stated in the original piece, sexual assaults tend to occur more often to single, young women away from home, what explains this? And I wonder how it can be that Winnipeg, which has something like 20 per cent per capita more initially reported sexual assaults than Toronto, can have almost none dismissed. It reads as if there are virtually no cases of false accusation or lack of evidence in Winnipeg compared to every other big city in the country. What would account for that? My guess is that we are looking not at some radically better policing but rather at some kind of reporting glitch.
It's the kind of question the data would suggest be answered, if the reporters didn't already know the  story was supposed to be.
Sigh.
Storification often betrays.

Comment: Look at Middle Ages and Reformation-era Europe before and during the time the USA was colonized.
Jews and the "wrong kind" of Christians were forcibly converted, had to flee, or were killed.
Look at Spain in 1492. NOT because of Christopher Columbus. But because Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand "celebrated" the unification of Spain by ordering all Jews to leave within two months, convert, or be executed. Many Jews left. Many Jews converted. But the Spanish Inquisition was suspicious of the conversions, fearing they weren't "sincere" enough. That's right, they told Jews convert or die, and when Jews converted, they wondered whether the conversion was sincere.
Martin Luther -- I assume you've heard of him -- preached the theology of Protestantism to the Jews. When the Jews weren't impressed, preferring their own faith, Martin Luther preached and wrote a bitter, cruel anti-Semitism, including burning down synagogues with the Jews inside.
"Convert or die" didn't originate with Islam.

Comment: It's interesting that the latest trend amongst his opponents is to talk about his "fitness" for office.
Well, here's the rub. There is no criteria for "fitness", nor will there be one US federal politician (Congressman or Senator) who will step forward and suggest it, because when they do they are all caught in the same web. As much as they all want to bellow at POTUS, they all know that once they set a criteria they all stand to be measured against it.
Likewise, as silly as it seems, they will never force the President to get a mental health examination. If they did that, and if he passed the test, which he probably would (there is a big difference between being "unfit" and being "outrageous"), he would have clinical proof that he is sane, and none of them - except Trump - want to live with that outcome.
So bellow as much as you want, POTUS is doing what he promised to do - upset the status quo. This is good for everyone. Bright minds will find a way to seize on this.

Comment: Ronnie, what does reserve mean?
Years ago, probably before the current body you reside in, some trucks came with two fuel tanks, one was the main tank and the other was the reserve tank. Sometimes, the driver of the truck would forget or intentionally resort to having to use the reserve tank. The reserve tank is designed to be used for what ever purpose the owner would deem necessary. So it really doesn't matter, but one thing is certain, the reserve is not intended to be a savings account. This is why the PF has an earnings reserve account and there is a CBR; one is intended to reserve funds for payment of dividends and part for government spending, the other is for when ever the legislature deems necessary. 
Personally, I would like to see spending and workforce reductions to 2009 levels prior to federal recovery programs, because we took hundreds of millions we really didn't need. Investing the reserve funds would have been nice but that is never what they were intended for.

Comment: I always enjoy Anita’s columns and appreciate the information she unearths. While a large bank account is better than a small one for a politician I would offer that there is more to the question than simple dollars in the bank.

 What’s missing in many analyses of political financial resources is the question of how these dollars are used to further the goal of being elected. Is it more or less effective to spend on signs hanging from homeowners fences rather than on coordinated web and social media campaigns or the very expensive television ads? Even the Dudleys and the Bergs could intelligently leverage the power of social media if they knew how. 

Money sitting in the bank is simply that. Sign waving, yard signs, and walking door-to-door with a stack of trifold brochures are relatively inexpensive strategies but are they really cost-effective in terms of votes delivered on election day in the second decade of the 21st century?

Comment: Religious liberties are not absolute.   If consciences are to be burdened by a generally applicable federal law that advances a compelling government interest, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act requires that this be done in the least restrictive way possible. It's not sufficient to maintain that such a burden only amounts to a remote material cooperation (e.g. opt-out accommodation); it's necessary to establish that no other way would be as practicable & effective. 

The question thus turns on the government showing that alternate distribution channels are infeasible. Since the Affordable Care Act model revolves around employment-based health insurance, the goverment has argued that requiring other distribution alternatives would upend that model, which the law, itself, presupposed as the most feasible means. That presupposition was already well founded & well grounded, as that model's feasibility had been empirically established and long-practiced. 

The need must be met somehow!

Comment: "exactly who do we want? From Where? Why? As long was the Canadian people are given the opportunity to decide..."

Exactly.

The notion that the people actually living in a country get to decide who can join them, not their rulers,  seems a difficult concept to some.

We are still living with the consequences of the times when the land belonged to rulers, and they got it by conquest, or marriage alliances, or bartering it with other rulers, and the people just came with it like livestock.

"Nationalism" came along with democracy, i.e. the revolutionary notion that a country belonged to its people, not its rulers, and they alone had the right to decide how it should be run, and who they would invite to join them.

Now we seem to have gone back full circle, with our rulers feeling they alone should decide, and the people should have no say.

Comment: I was in a situation much like this a few years ago. If you want to go after lost benefits, start by filing for unemployment. Determining Employee/Contractor status is one of their steps to determining eligibility. If you've been filing taxes as a contractor, you may be eligible for some IRS refunds. Contact the IRS and file an SS-8 ASAP because another year will fall off if you wait to Jan 01. (It takes at least 6 months for an official determination but the date is based on when you filed.) Based on the information provided above I believe the determinations would be that you are in fact an employee.

Employee/Contractor status is determined by who has "control" while you are working not an agreement upon hiring. The less say you have regarding when/where/how you work the more likely you are an employee.

Additional Reading:
https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/independent-contractor-self-employed-or-employee

Comment: Robert Reich's Four Big Conservative Lies

Lie number one: The rich and CEOs are America’s job creators. So we dare not tax them.

The truth is the middle class and poor are the job-creators through their purchases of goods and services. If they don’t have enough purchasing power because they’re not paid enough, companies won’t create more jobs and our economy won’t grow.


Lie number two: People are paid what they’re worth in the market. So we shouldn’t tamper with pay.
The facts contradict this. CEOs who got 30 times the pay of typical workers 40 years ago now get 300 times their pay not because they’ve done such a great job but because they control their compensation committees and their stock options have ballooned.

Meanwhile, most American workers earn less today than they did 40 years ago, adjusted for inflation, not because they’re working less hard now but because they don’t have strong unions bargaining for them.

On strict Constitutional principle, I oppose *any* federal government involvement in health care or coverage other than in its role as an employer.

Get the federal government out of health care and coverage. Reduce our federal income and excise taxes commensurately and let states and localities do as they like. "Promote the general welfare" does not mean "provide" it or to provide *for* it. If we want the federal government involved in health care or coverage then we should first amend the Constitution to provide that specific authority.

Until we do...it doesn't have it.

Comment: How quickly we forget our past. How self-centered we have become. Yes, work is hard. Yes, stress is an integral part of work (and life in general). Stress is what provides the motivation to improve our lot, avoid danger, overcome obstacles. After reading this despairing article, one might think that modern times have been beset by miseries and calamities previously unheard of. Oy. Allow me to provide a frame of reference for the author, before we find him teetering from some elevated landmark. In the Middle Ages, the average person lived to 31. I'm certain that the lack of proper medical care, clean water and general hygiene, and indentured service to the local lord may have affected that number. In the Industrial Revolution, people routinely worked 14-16 hour days in terrible conditions (smoke, dust, unsafe machinery). There were no sick days or holiday time (overtime pay? Seriously?). Child labor was rampant and remorseless. Consider this the next time you feel pressure at your job.

Comment: You say I'm conceding a point that I never addressed, let alone denied? Even by your shoddy standards of debate, that's a classic.

"Bylaws and their amendments are government actions subject to the Charter, whether they are voted in by residents or elected municipal councillors."

Scarlet red herring. The constitutionality of the bylaw isn't in question. Nor was any change to the bylaw being proposed.. What was proposed was a change in the zoning designation of a piece of land. Such matters are, quite properly, up to a community to decide. The community didn't originally intend for the land to be used as a cemetery, and they chose to leave it that way. It's a tough break for those who wanted to build their cemetery. But nothing stops them from applying again in the future, or seeking other land with the necessary zoning already in place. 

When the Supreme Court decides to read the minds of voters and over-rule their democratic choice, please let me know.

Comment: Or shovels. 

I think we will quickly find out what we already know: Walls and fences are expensive, and by themselves do not make for great security. Smugglers are already going over, under, around, and through our existing fences. Building a longer one won't solve that. In the end, what it will really take is people. We can (and should) use physical barriers and technology (cameras, sensors, etc.), but without adequate manpower to detect and respond to intrusions, this is all for naught. No wall or motion detector is going to handcuff those who get past it. And people will get past it. Given enough time, ingenuity, resources and motivation (money), folks will figure out how.

Comment: Must be RRSP season. 

I am one of those fortunate people that was raised by an educated, single mom, the daughter of immigrants who came to Canada in the early 1900s who made it through the hungry 30s. I had my first job at 10 years old delivering groceries in a wagon . I have pictures of this. I kept my earnings in a secret wooden box I hid in my closet. My mom found it and chastised me for not putting it in a bank to earn 2% compounded interest. She showed me a calculation how my money could grow. She also taught me to invest in War bonds which also earned a bit more interest.

Since age 10, I have always saved and had the magic of compounding my money. I graduated in engineering from UBC with two degrees, debt free in my first and money in the bank after my second. Today, in retirement, I still invest in Cdn blue chip stocks that pay at least a 4% dividend. 

I invested in RRSPs, a big mistake. I earn way more in retirement than when I worked and now I pay big taxes on RRIF exit.

For me, this issue comes down to integrity. The business community was sold a bill of goods by the city that this new tax was going to be used exclusively for arterial road repairs. They largely supported taking ownership of that infrastructure expense. The debt service piece was a city decision after the fact. There are two candidates who intend to honor the purpose of this tax - Swansen and Berrios. Berrios even had evidence at the debate to prove the original intent of B&O.  As a citizen and tax payer, wouldn't you want the leader of the city to keep their promises and not unfairly tax you because they cannot keep expenses in line?

Comment: Under  29 U.S.C. § 141-197 of 1947, better known as the Taft-Hartley Act, the president can impose an 80 day cooling-off period prior to a contract expiring. After expiration, there is no "cooling off." In cases deemed to be National Emergencies, the President can directly intervene in a strike. Presidents since Truman have been rather reluctant to invoke the provisions of the Act.

Comment: Rationing is also hidden by rules.  In San Diego for example, another medicaid expansion state, Medical officially covers dental expenses.   What they don't mention is that the rules are growing ever more stringent.  No one can simply go to a dentist and have their teeth checked and cleaned.  Rules say each and every billable item must be a separate appointment and only one appointment can ever be scheduled.  The patient must actually wait a month or two for an appointment, wait a few hours in the office to have the teeth  checked, wait again to make an appointment to have the teeth cleaned, wait a month or two for the cleaning appointment, then wait a few hours in the office to have the teeth cleaned.  If any work is required, each item such as each filling, must similarly be one at a time.  You  can see how it easily would require a year to get a few fillings done, plus days and days off work while sitting in the waiting rooms.  But on paper, Medical covers dental care.

Comment: As some have mentioned, this comes year after year.  In fact, Peter Cheney wrote this column almost two years ago.  Here are some thoughts:

1.  There is no benefit to allowing the car to idle to operating temperature compared to driving it under light load.  Both techniques warm the engine with very similar wear and tear on the engine.  The benefit of driving is simply that at least you're moving while you burn gas.
2.  If you're idling the car to allow the interior to warm sufficiently to allow the interior of the car windows to defrost, the solution is found the night before.  For the last few hundred feet of your drive, open the windows.  This allows the humidity that has built up in the car to be removed.  There will be no moisture in the air to cause frost.  Of course, turn the defrost on in the morning to keep your breath away from windows.
3.  Knock the snow of your boots before getting in the car to avoid the build-up of snow, which leads to water, which leads to humidity.

Comment: i know you will challenge my statement on productivity, so allow me to explain. If a supervisor (company man) writes up a union employee for a justified reason, the unions first reaction is to grieve the disciplinary action (1st step). if the supervisor stands by their decision and maintains the discipline, the union will grieve it again, this (2nd step) requires the union representatives (usually 3-4 employees) to engage the upper management (usually 3-4 employees) to argue the case. this could take several hours. if again the union is not satisfied they press the issue to the (3rd step) where by the corporate leaders and main union leaders are flown in to sit down with those same 6-8 employees and hash it out again, usually another several hours. if again, the union is not satisfied they then push it to arbitration, whereby we now have lawyers and a judge involved, which could take weeks and even months to settle. all in all, lost time and productivity over a justified action.

Comment: The distorted and superficial reporting of facts about bees and bee populations in this story by Canadian Press is disappointing. The number of honey bee colonies in Canada has been increasing for years, reaching 750,000 in 2016. A recent review by a team at the University of Guelph found scare evidence that wild bee numbers are declining in Canada with the exception of 1-3 species (out of more than 800). And any consideration of the effects of neonicotinoid insecticides on bees must also recognize the risks to pollinators which would occur should Canada shift to the use of older pesticides to protect food crops, as has occurred in Europe. There are major threats to bee vitality in Canada, but these are primarily pests like Varroa mites, viruses and other diseases, and indeed the pesticides which beekeepers use themselves - again as emphasized in the recent University of Guelph revue.

Comment: "The state response will help determine whether new companies will be able to establish a strong presence on the North Slope in competition with ConocoPhillips, BP and Exxon."   The cartel on the slope decides who it`s competition is on the slope. They control access to the oil/gas/water separation and treatment facilities. And that`s the way it`s been since first oil. The same three companies own the rights to Prudhoe oil and gas, the same three control capacity in the system as well as own the TAPS oil line to Valdez. They also own the deep water shipping facilities.  That`s a hard monopoly for even the state, let alone a subsidized Caelus, to crack, without incurring what in the past was usurious costs to explorers/developers (now the state!).  
SB21 perpetuated that stranglehold on the bulk of the state`s oil resource development by the three remaining cartel members who signed the "Prudhoe Bay Joint-operating-Unit Agreement, which gives each one a veto over the other two.

Comment: I was working for the Alaska Railroad as a fork lift operator in Denali at the old depot. It was the summer of 99 and my first morning opening up the building around 5 or 6 am. As I crossed the tracks towards the depot I spotted this large mass to my left. Thirty feet down the tracks a Lynx stood going the other way, and it was staring me down. I froze. It looked the size of a Labrador, with matted twisted hair like dreadlocks. A moment passed with little pace. Then the gigantic cat put it's nose to the ground with ears fidgeting.  And with an unsettling grace of movement it made its way to the tree line and vanished silently. My heart was pounding.

Comment: There's precious little equal opportunity in the US today. Yes, people have access to primary and secondary education, but the education on offer at various school districts varies widely in terms of quality. They often don't have time (or the contacts) for internships, or extra classes, or those other experiences that help make one more successful later. 

Finally, lots of people are denied employment because of gender and race. Sexual harassment remains a pervasive problem.

Comment: There is no softer outlook for inflation as there are still big price increases coming up in the next few months. Both the CPI and the CPIH are in any case dysfunctional measures of inflation for a central bank, since they exclude changes in housing prices, which even now are still rising faster than prices in general. Until the ONS publishes a monthly UK HICP with an owner-occcupied housing component based on the net acquisitions approach, the best monthly inflation measure for the Bank of England to target would be the RPI excluding mortgage interest payments and council tax with a formula effect adjustment. The inflation rate of this series was 3.2% in July, up from 3.0% in June. This estimate itself is on the low side, since the ONS hasn’t added stamp duty to the RPI as it should have done. In any case, properly measured, inflation is already above the 3% upper bound. The bank rate should be raised at the next opportunity. It should never have been lowered in the first place.

Comment: All contract negotiations have to go on within the law. The courts have made it clear that PERS retirement agreements cannot be unilaterally retroactively negated.  It is true that we all have to step up to pay employees what is required by law. But it's not true that nothing has been done. PERS benefits have been "reformed" (benefits reduced) more than 20 times since 1995. Over the years, PERS has been overfunded and underfunded. That's the way long term investments of this sort work. The current crisis we face is partly due to changes in economic growth and in returns on investments, but it is partly due to the legislature's attempts to further reduce PERS benefits in a way that violates law. We have had enough of that. The State has to look elsewhere besides old folks' retirements for new sources of revenue to pay the bills. Most PERS retirement benefits are quite modest. We need an overhaul of our rickety and unstable tax system. It's wasteful and it does not meet our needs.

Comment: There are two ways to put a number on crimes. You can ask how many get tracked by police from reports to them by victims. Or you can have people self-report in a poll, no police involved.

With the first method, the number of police-reported sexual assaults has declined by about 20% in past years, in keeping with drops of some other crimes by over 20%. So the picture is crimes are dropping in frequency, and a variety of crimes fit this trend, including sexual assaults. And this would not be surprising, as Canada is an aging population, with fewer males in their teens, 20s and 30s, when most violent crimes are performed (males are more often perpetrators of violent crimes).

But with the second method, self-reporting in a poll, the exact same rates of self-reported sexual assault have stayed constant and not budged at all.

Given that MASSIVE gulf in alignment, it is strange that the reporter selects only quotes from people convinced that the second method perfectly reflects truth.

> “For those people it is a fact,” Mr. Tory said. “Real people have become ‘fake news.’ I don’t understand.”

Key words are "they think". Article over in the Toronto Star cites 'Transit Planners' at Ryerson University who ran simulations of trips in Scarborough and concluded the 1-stop Rob Ford Folly subway extension would be faster than existing or proposed LRT alternatives. Comment: Despite comments about climate change being a hoax or just part of natural cycles, the evidence is pretty clear that human activities have caused climate change. I'd submit that we are already paying a "carbon tax" every time we have to pay to build or retro-fit coastal infrastructure, relocate a component of our economy out of state (oyster hatcheries and associated jobs relocated to Hawaii),  see salmon numbers drop due to poor ocean conditions, or see forest lands and timber yield impacted by drier summers.  Now, in our local area, we are contemplating building a reservoir to capture water from the Dungeness, due to lack of snowfall in the mountains. This is a type of carbon tax that will only increase if we don't mitigate the problem ourselves.

Comment: I hope our railroad (we own it) finds a way to keep the maintenance schedules from falling behind.  The ARR is a vital link to the interior. As vital as any port that it connects to.  
I hope we don`t let such a gem and attraction languish and become a third rate slow and dying dinosaur.  Our railroad is known the world over for it`s scenery and pioneer aura, as well as being vital to keeping our freight costs down(freight by rail AND water)  on outside goods coming into Alaska.  
  One can complain, like Senator Micciche did, about having to pay for that new auto-braking system, but just remember the recent train incidents that WOULD have been prevented by this system, had they met the FRA installation timelines without seeking multiple delays as we did.  
It`s needed even more so on a single track railroad where passenger trains and freight trains commonly run together in opposite directions, interspersed with crews trying to work on the tracks and bridges and ditches.

Comment: We are obliged to keep forgiving. The individual seeking forgiveness must ask for it, be it from God or fellow human.

Judaism teaches those who have done wrong  seek forgiveness. The offender must sincerely ask pardon and seek to correct the wrongs he has done. After a certain point-- three sincere apologies, an attempt at restitution, a clear indication that the person has changed - it becomes the obligation of the wronged party to forgive. 

The rabbis agree that teshuvah (repentance) requires five elements: recognition of one's sins as sins (hakarát ha-chét'), remorse (charatá), desisting from sin (azivát ha-chét'), restitution where possible (peira'ón), and confession (vidúi). The tradition is also quite clear, however, that  if they are done without desisting from sin, they do not constitute teshuva.

What Jesus changed was the number of time we should forgive. The rest reads like a manual for the sacrament of Penance.

Comment: As you've pointed out, if the matter is resolved before an inquiry is held there are a number of remedies available. However, the context here is that of an inquiry. Respectfully, the author and you could have stated the matter in a better way. An inquiry finding that points to misconduct- for which you both use the term "censure"- isn't a remedy. In other words it's just a diagnosis, not a treatment. Unless I'm mistaken, the only treatment the inquiry can recommend is, metaphorically-speaking, to kill the patient. It seems the CJC and others recognize that problem.

In addition to recommending removal, it's logical that an inquiry would be able to recommend any of the remedial measures that the review panel can choose. By eliminating that option, errors or omissions at the review level cannot be corrected once they're passed to an inquiry.

Comment: I know of a couple of parishes where the sanctuary is alarmed.  Sometimes the Blessed Sacarament is placed on the altar (in the sanctuary) in a monstrance for adoration--from the nave.  Likewise, at least in a Catholic church, Stations of the Cross are hung in the nave, not the sanctuary.

During the Mass the demarcation between nave and sanctuary symbolically separates the heavenly and earthly action.  (Which is one of the reasons receiving our Lord at the rail instead of at the head of a queue is such a beautiful thing.)  It remains set aside for this purpose and few others even when Mass is not offered.  Typically when vespers or other hours are prayed they are only led from the sanctuary if led by a vested priest or deacon, and even then not always.  

Why open up the sanctuary for devotions that have for centuries taken place in the nave?  And where in the sanctuary do you intend for people to pray the rosary or stations?

Comment: It seems that Mr Pape ought to do proper research, by discounting this ETF by saying it has paid no distributions. Even a cursory look at the basics, such as with their TSX TR ETF (HXT), makes the point that the prices roll in the distributions so that there's no periodic tax liability from monthly or quarterly payments. Instead, the unit price incorporates the dividends, and you settle up with the taxman via capital gains/losses when the holding is liquidated.

If you don't trust that the dividends are built-in, then so be it, but this makes for much less ACB bookkeeping, and may also be a relief from automatic tax withholdings in taxable accounts, though not sure how that works in international holdings.

Point is that no distributions may be a good thing, for tax reasons, and maintaining your ACB records for the CRA.

Mr. Pape's self-promotion often digs into ancient history to point out his old ideas, forgetting how acting at that time would have tanked for anyone who bit!

Comment: 1) They are both in Canada.
Yes. Correct.
2) They are now regulated in a similar fashion provincially
Not at all.
3) They are subject to foreign speculation and they are attractive places to live. 
Sure.

Here's some other differences:
1) Vancouver has about 1500 more people per square kilometre living in it. And that includes Stanley Park, which alone accounts for about 4% of non-habitable land in the city.
2) BC gives it's home owners free tax credits every year. Free money, just for owning a home. Every year.
3) Property tax in Vancouver is about a third of taxes in Toronto.
4) Prices for almost everything, not just real estate, are higher in BC than Ontario. Purchasing power is marketably different between the two provinces.

Comment: Onerightstand, stated "What do you think people did before health care insurance????".  Glad you asked.

Up until the 20's and 30's people either bartered for a visit to or from a doctor.  Or, they died if there was no access.  Period.  The discussions about health insurance for the masses happen for a reason -- to help people that create larger monetary burden on the system if they don't have it.  Tricare, Medicaid, Chip (for kids), and Medicare, all because it was needed.  (BTW, Medicare is not "free" (as some think), nor is it 100% government run, you need a private plan/s in addition to 'Medicare Plan A and B'.)

So, why do you think there have been discussions about health insurance?

In the olden days, before insurance came into being, family members stayed in one location.  Parents, grandparents, brothers, sisters, aunts, uncles, etc, were not scattered all over the country, nor were they as independent from each other.  They acted as a bartering unit when care was needed.

Comment: Sorry Lumen, I object vehemently to the attempt to associate oppressive bureaucracy as an inherent component of socialism. That notion arises entirely from the Soviet system that centralized virtually all modes of production; and even then, fairness requires comparing that bureaucracy to the enormous corporate income tax bureaucracy in capitalism (both in government and industry) which the soviets did not have.

There are other ways to socialize production (without the stupidity of soviet centralization) that require no more bureaucracy that in capitalism--a government can be the sole shareholder in an airline or railway or steel plant, and just receive dividends, for instance. 

More importantly, the elements of social economy being considered these days are not the means of production, but rather the provision of social services.

More or less bureaucracy is, I suggest, ultimately a function of government rather than economic system. There is more than one way to skin a cat.

Comment: "You trust your sources like The Toronto Star, Globe, CBC, CNN, NYTimes, how are they any better than Fox or Brierbart. Not sure you believe in your rhetoric."

It is difficult to respond to a quote like this without running afoul of the censors. To claim that Breitbart, or Fox News, are journalistic equivalents of the NYT or Globe and Mail is absurd. To make such a claim in a public forum is a partial explanation for the success of Trump's war on the media. When a venerable institution like the NYT, winner of dozens of Pulitzers, one of the most trusted newspapers on the planet, is equated with Breitbart, a site established with the express purpose of publishing biased work, and then morphed by Bannon into the self-admitted heart of the alt-right, there is no hope of reasonable discussion, no possibility of meaningful dialog. If people actually believe that there is no qualitative difference between Breitbart and the NYT, Those people forfeit the right to be taken seriously.

Comment: Without oil you wouldn't be fishing and neither would 99 percent of the other fishermen.
Commercial fishing has so decimated  the stocks that once prolific streams and rivers no longer have runs and many runs have to be enhanced by hatcheries. Hatcheries are the one bright point that commercial fisheries are mostly responsible for. Halibut stocks are horribly depleted, and no it wasn't the sports fishery that did it. 95 percent of halibut are allocated to the commercial fishery, 5 percent to sports fishing. 
The commercial fishing industry doesn't contribute a tenth of what the oil industry does to the economy of Alaska. It has been great for a few privileged families and the conglomerates in Seattle but not so much for the average Alaskan.

Comment: This outcome vindicates the traditional rubric that you cannot use microeconomic principles and strategies to determine macroeconomic policies. It's a classic case of fallacy of composition: that is, what is good for the individual is not good for all.

In health insurance it's great for the individual to avoid paying premiums when you are young and invincible, and start when you're old and decrepit, but that type of selection bias will not sustain a viable system.

What I don't understand, as an economist, is why Trump has no economists in his cabinet, and there are very few, if any, in Congress. No wonder they can't get anything to work!

Comment: Yes, calling an election with a 20 point lead in the polls is primarily a politically opportunistic move but it is also a practical move inasmuch as PM May naturally wants the strongest possible majority going into the Brexit negotiations.

Former UK PM Cameron showed a great deal of class and respect for democracy by resigning after Brexit when he didn't have to and this would never be done here, especially by Liberal leaders who tend to leave only when forced by electoral defeat or internal revolt regardless of the good of the country.

After 2 unnecessary elections by Chretien who had a solid majority and no issue nor need but greed to call these elections more than a year short of the normal time, PM Harper later introduced a resolution that binds the government to fixed four year terms unless it has a minority and is defeated in the house.  

So is this  a flaw in the British parliamentary system or really IMHO the flaw of Liberal arrogance, authoritarianism and love of power?

Comment: Measure 97 is the first chance in 26 years to undo the tremendous damage that has been done to Oregon's schools and public sector by the narrow passage of Measure 5 in November 1990.  While marketed as a solution to ever-rising property taxes (yes, a fix was necessary, especially for people on fixed incomes and for small farmers), Measure 5 wound up producing billions of dollars in savings for large property-owning companies.  Most of these companies are out-of-state corporations.  They have been  Measure 5's winners for a quarter century.  The rest of us have paid the price.  Measure 97 finally restores a measure (no pun!) of fairness to Oregon's tax system.

Comment: Actually, based on the link you provided, your claim is false.  He did not say "the homeless are worse than a rat infestation."

Based on your link, this is what he said:

“You don’t want to make analogies that sound inhumane, but when you have, having cleaned up one of the big homeless (camps) on the Waianae Coast, you would have been better off to have a rat infestation,” Carlisle said during an editorial board meeting at Civil Beat headquarters last week.

“There were needles, there were condoms with drugs in them, there was glass everywhere. The cigarette butts are all over the place. It’s not safe to walk on it. Every mattress that you find that you have to dig up, it’s got lice. They’ve got dogs, they’ve got feces. You’ve got all these vile smells,” Carlisle said. “It’s just God-awful.”

And he was right.  Some of these encampments are absolutely awful, and making excuses for people who live in filth does not help them.  Nor does lying about descriptions of those encampments.

Comment: Galactic Hero: The issue is not aircraft design but air density -- which is, in part, determined by temperature. Higher temperature correlates with lower air density, which offers less lift. While next-generation aircraft will likely benefit from incremental advances in propulsion and aerodynamics, it is difficult to imagine large increases in power/weight ratios and lift using conventional technology common to commercial aircraft for the last 50 years. The problem is in the physics.
